docs.lead_paragraph: Turnover is so uncommon here that legislators are as likely to die in office as to be voted out. So when some county officials threatened last week to see some lawmakers defeated this year at the polls, it was an attack on a way of life that legislators have almost come to see as a perk of the job -- an entitlement, practically, to be re-elected until the political will or ability to breathe runs out, whichever comes first. As of 2002, according to figures compiled by the National Conference of State Legislatures, state lawmakers around the country had won about 92 percent of their re-election bids over the previous two decades. In New York, the figure was more than 98 percent.
docs.abstract: Threats by county officials across New York State to challenge re-election of incumbent lawmakers who pass expensive legislation, like Medicaid laws, then leave measures up to counties to finance do not seem worry legislators, who have been re-elected 98 percent of time over past two decades; Democrats blame Gov George E Pataki and claim that counties have not supplied them with list of items they want cut; Republicans do not see threat as serious and ask county politicians for time to address problems (M)
docs.snippet: Turnover is so uncommon here that legislators are as likely to die in office as to be voted out. So when some county officials threatened last week to see some lawmakers defeated this year at the polls, it was an attack on a way of life that...

docs.lead_paragraph: Right before Christmas, Jamie McConnell arrived at the Lake Country School here, as he does most days of the week, to pick up his son, Ben, 3. Hardly short on spunk, Ben made his way out to the snowy playground, and Mr. McConnell, as parents have done since the dawn of swings and monkey bars, trailed behind. Mr. McConnell had plenty of time to watch Ben romp and to invite one of his classmates and his mother home for peanut butter and jelly sandwiches.

headline.main: Two Fathers, With One Happy to Stay at Home

docs.abstract: Emerging population of gay men are not only raising children but also committed to idea that one parent should leave workplace to do it; census returns of same-sex couples with children, randomly picked, show 26 percent of male couples include stay-at-home parent; figure is one percentage point more than for married couples with children and four percentage points higher than for female couples; percentage of men who stay at home is significantly smaller among married heterosexual couples; some gay men are pursuing parenthood with fervor, having faced obstacles of finding surrogate mothers and of discriminatory adoption laws that favor heterosexual couples; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE is something about being far from home that can short-circuit rational judgment, particularly when it comes to engaging in leisure activities that would normally inspire the response, ''Are you nuts?'' That phenomenon occurred to me most recently when considering a $3 parasailing ride on a beach in Mexico -- a plan aborted after the owner of a nearby resort graphically described various accidents he'd witnessed involving landings that weren't exactly soft.
docs.abstract: Susan Stellin Practical Traveler column offers advice on instruction and research that would be beneficial to novices considering scuba diving during vacations, particularly in foreign countries; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: THERE is something about being far from home that can short-circuit rational judgment, particularly when it comes to engaging in leisure activities that would normally inspire the response, ''Are you nuts?''     That phenomenon occurred to me most...

docs.lead_paragraph: At 51, with college still ahead for his two teenage children, Lee Hutchison had no intention of retiring from FedEx, where he had worked for 21 years. But a few months ago, that is just what he did. ''It was so far from my mind, early retirement,'' he said. ''I was in a department that wrote manuals for our aircraft engineers. We were very well respected. But when they made that retirement offer, they in effect defined a group of employees that they were saying, 'We need you to leave.' It took a little while for it to dawn on me that I was part of that group.''

headline.main: Incentives Lure Many to Quit, Even With a Lean Job Market

docs.abstract: Thousands of Americans are taking employers up on generous incentive offers and retiring early, gambling on finding something else in lean job market; workers like Lee Hutchinson, 51, who had no intention of leaving FedEx, are taking fortified pension payments and promises of health benefits; such offers, which drew few takers until year or two ago, are now more carefully aimed at workers in shrinking operations; 3,600 of 14,000 eligible FedEx workers left in Oct and Verion has shed ten percent of work force; several of those taking offers explain; photos (M)
docs.snippet: At 51, with college still ahead for his two teenage children, Lee Hutchison had no intention of retiring from FedEx, where he had worked for 21 years. But a few months ago, that is just what he did.    ''It was so far from my mind, early...

docs.lead_paragraph: CHANCES are that you have a family physician for regular checkups, but it is not likely that you have a personal lawyer to call for routine legal matters. According to the American Bar Association, half of all consumers who need a lawyer do not seek legal help. The reasons include cost and uncertainty: many people say they do not know how to find a good attorney. This potential demand is fueling the growth of prepaid legal-services plans, also known as legal H.M.O.'s. The plans can be bought individually or obtained through some employee benefits packages.

headline.main: Personal Business; The H.M.O. Approach to Choosing a Lawyer

docs.abstract: Uncertainty about how to choose a good lawyer is fueling growth of prepaid legal-services plans, also known as legal HMO's; plans can be bought individually or obtained through some employee benefits packages; like health maintenance organizations, legal plans typically charge monthly fee, or premium, often $10 to $25; that buys access to network of lawyers in private practice; lawyers usually provide set package of free services, like document review, will preparation and representation in real estate transactions; photo (L)
docs.snippet: CHANCES are that you have a family physician for regular checkups, but it is not likely that you have a personal lawyer to call for routine legal matters. According to the American Bar Association, half of all consumers who need a lawyer do not seek...

docs.lead_paragraph: The 2,000 people, the worried well, who come each year to Memorial Sloan-Kettering's cancer prevention center will learn that many cancers can, in fact, be prevented, and that it is up to them to have the appropriate medical tests and to live right. For their $2,000 fee, most of which is paid by health insurance, they may be steered to smoking cessation sessions, or watch a cooking demonstration and hear a talk by a nutritionist. They will learn the early signs and symptoms of cancer and they almost certainly will have a cancer screening test.

headline.main: Cancer 'Prevention' Is Big Seller, But Medical Experts Are Divided

docs.abstract: Cancer prevention programs, encompassing anything from screenings to smoking cessation and dietary education, have become financial mainstay for major medical institutions such as Memorial Sloan-Kettering and M D Anderson Cancer Center, which is building huge new center for prevention; experts in fiercely competitive world of cancer medicine are divided, noting that for now most efforts involve research that may or may not lead to clinical advances; National Institutes of Health also requires designated comprehensive cancer centers to have prevention component; Dr Donald Berry and others like Dr Michael Gallo worry that many people exaggerate their cancer risk and have inflated expectations about what science can do to protect them; photo of Dr Moshe Shike of Memorial Sloan-Kettering (M)
docs.snippet: The 2,000 people, the worried well, who come each year to Memorial Sloan-Kettering's cancer prevention center will learn that many cancers can, in fact, be prevented, and that it is up to them to have the appropriate medical tests and to live right. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Charles Schumer and Paul Craig Roberts (Op-Ed, Jan. 6) illustrate their doubts about free trade in the modern global economy with the following example: ''Within five years the number of radiologists in this country is expected to decline significantly because M.R.I. data can be sent over the Internet to Asian radiologists capable of diagnosing the problem at a small fraction of the cost.''
docs.abstract: Letter from Prof Richard S Grossman says he would applaud anything that brings down skyrocketing cost of health care, such as outsourcing of diagnostic testing mentioned in Jan 6 Op-Ed on free trade

docs.lead_paragraph: FUNDS that owned small-company stocks and value stocks were among the biggest winners in the fourth quarter of 2003, but all major categories grew robustly, according to Morningstar Inc. Managers of three of the top-performing actively managed funds that are open to new investors talked about what led to their strong results and about their outlook for 2004.

headline.main: Mutual Funds Report; In a Good Year, These Funds Managed to Do Even Better

docs.abstract: Managers of three of top-performing mutual funds that are open to new investors comment on what led to their strong results in 2003 and on their outlook for 2004; they are Derek N Rollingson, manager of Icon Materials fund, Jean-Pierre Conreur, manager of Tocqueville Small Cap Value fund, and Robert E Killen and Lee S Grout, managers of Berwyn Fund; graphs show funds' performance; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''And You Thought Pension Funds Were Scary'' (Market Watch, Dec. 14), Gretchen Morgenson's column about the funding of future retiree medical obligations, sounded an alarm where none was warranted.

headline.main: Paying the Price Of Retirees' Health Care

docs.abstract: Letter from Mary Beth Bardin, executive vice president of Verizon Communications, holds Dec 14 Market Watch column, about funding of future retiree medical obligations, sounded an alarm where none was warranted

docs.lead_paragraph: USUALLY, it's union organizers who declare themselves to be the voice of disenfranchised workers, while management counters that the workers have been misinformed and misled. But this fall, after the failure of a rival union's campaign to recruit the work force of North Hills Office Services in Woodbury, one of Long Island's biggest commercial cleaning companies, the roles were reversed.

headline.main: A Union Battles to Represent the Island's Janitors

docs.abstract: Article on recruitment drive by Service Employees International Union Local 32BJ aimed at persuading 400 workers at North Hills Office Services in Woodbury, one of Long Island's biggest commercial cleaning companies, to leave National Organization of Industrial Trade Unions; photo (M)
